greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest integer that, upon multiplying any divisor of A025487(n), produces a member of A025487.
comment: All terms also belong to A181818. Each member of A181818 appears infinitely often. a(A025487(m)) = a(A025487(n)) iff A025487(m) and A025487(n) have the same odd part (cf. A000265).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: If A025487(n) = Product p(i)^e(i), then a(n) = Product A002110(i-1)^e(i); i.e., a(n) = A181811(A025487(n)).
example: For any divisor d of 6 (d = 1, 2, 3, 6), 2*d (2, 4, 6, 12) is always a member of A025487. 2 is the smallest number with this relationship to 6; therefore, since 6 = A025487(4), a(4) = 2.
results.author: _Matthew Vandermast_, Nov 30 2010
